newsitem.title: USA: ABA's Fox says Levitt "arrogant" on pay-to-play.
newsitem.headline: ABA's Fox says Levitt "arrogant" on pay-to-play.

text.p: The chairman of a key American Bar Association panel lashed out at SEC Chairman Arthur Levitt who charged on Thursday that lawyers are dodging their responsility on pay-to-play.
"It's a shame. His arrogance shocks me," Larry Fox, chair of ABA's influential standing committee on ethics said in a telephone interview.
"He refuses to recognize the concerns we've raised. He and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York (have) come up with a proposal that makes no sense," added Fox.

Levitt, who said Thursday that lawyers are dragging their feet in adopting an effective pay-to-play ban, favors a New York City bar proposal modeled largely after a tough Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board curb on bond dealer contributions called G-37.
"It's just a dumb rule," said Fox, referring to the City bar's proposal. "It needs more study."

But Paul Maco, director of SEC's Office of Municipal Securities, said, "It's interesting that many of the objections that have been raised in the debate regarding lawyers' pay-to-play are exactly the same as those raised three years ago with respect to G-37. (Yet) the result has passed muster with flying colors."
